videos.title: The Unstoppable Rise Of LG TVs (There's No Catching Up)
videos.description: üí° Turn any idea into a production-ready app or website by describing it to AI. Dream it, and Lindy builds it from coding to QA. Try Lindy today using my link üëâüèª https://go.lindy.ai/logically-answered   In the early 2010s, OLED was a joke. Too fragile, too expensive, and impossible to scale. Everyone dropped it except LG. Fast forward to today, and LG owns over half the global OLED market. They even make panels for Samsung and Sony. So what did LG see that everyone else missed? Back in the 2000s, the TV world was all Plasma and LCD. Plasma had the best picture but came with heat, power, and burn-in issues. LCDs were cheap, efficient, and ‚Äúgood enough.‚Äù While everyone chased scale, LG doubled down on quality. They bought Kodak‚Äôs OLED patents, poured billions into R&D, and invented WRGB OLED to cut costs. For years, it looked like financial suicide. But when Netflix, gaming, and home theaters exploded, OLED became the gold standard. By 2016, LG had perfected manufacturing, and by 2017, the C7 OLED changed everything. Competitors mocked OLED, then bought LG panels anyway. Now, LG Display supplies Samsung, Sony, and nearly every major brand. The bet no one believed in became the tech no one could live without.  Timestamps: 0:00 - OLED 0:35 - All In 4:10 - Doubling Down 9:53 - The Empire  Resources:  https://pastebin.com/ywMnAEK0  Disclosure: This video is sponsored by Lindy. Some of the links in this description may be affiliate links, which means I may earn a small commission at no additional cost to you.

videos.title: Best TV of 2025 (Shootout): LG G5 vs Samsung S95F vs Sony BRAVIA 8 II vs Panasonic Z95B
videos.description: Our 2025 TV shootout between the LG G5 & Panasonic Z95B 4-stack WOLED TVs + Samsung S95F & Sony BRAVIA 8 II QD-OLEDs.  All competing TVs were 55 inches in screen size, and were calibrated in SDR and HDR modes to the common standards used within the film and broadcast industry, perceptually matched to a Sony BVM-HX3110 dual-layer LCD mastering monitor capable of reaching a peak brightness of 4000 nits.  All the TVs were masked, so the 6 video professional & sole enthusiast judges didn't know which TV was which when scoring different picture attributes.  00:00 Intro 00:21 Near-black 00:57 Colours 02:12 HDR 03:38 Motion 04:31 Uniformity 05:02 Video processing 05:52 Bright room 06:14 Out of The Box 06:48 Best Home Cinema TV 07:33 Best Living Room TV 11:23 Best TV of 2025 12:37 Shootout format  The judges were (in alphabetical order by surname):  1. Zeb Chadfield, Founder & Chief Vision Officer at The Finish Line 2. Maciej Koper, Professional Calibrator & Reviewer at Wybierz.tv & Choose.tv 3. Ian Lowe, ex-Dolby Vision Post Production 4. James Meredith, Technical Director & Co-Founder at Netvio 5. Julian Nelson, Head of Post Production & Co-Founder at Residence Pictures 6. Luis Pinhao, Imaging Engineer at Cinelab Ltd 7. Robert Walia, TV enthusiast    The results neither represent the opinions or views of individual judges, nor do they constitute the endorsement of any particular TV brand, since the judges didn‚Äôt even know which TV was which throughout the voting process.  Thanks to award-winning UK electrical retailer Crampton & Moore for supplying the TVs & organising the shootout. If you're interested in purchasing a new TV, even if it's not the LG G5, Panasonic Z95B, Samsung S95F or Sony XR80M2, please support this channel by considering buying from Crampton & Moore... call 01423 569249 or email david.conner@cramptonandmoore.co.uk  Thanks to professional AV mounting specialist B-Tech International Group for loaning the BTF841 universal dual-stack floor stands for the shootout. For more information, please visit: https://www.btechavmounts.com/  Thanks to content distribution specialist Netvio for loaning the 8x8 matrix for the shootout. Netvio provide a wide range of high quality, Ultra High Definition HDMI distribution products using several different technologies including Fibre, AV over IP and HDBaseT, with unique AV control apps, control system drivers and software. You can find more information at https://www.netvio.co.uk  Thanks to HDMI 2.1 cable manufacturer Zeskit for supplying all the HDMI cables used at the shootout. comments.comment_text_display:
usually ... when we say " once you go ultrawide, you will never go back" ... most of the time, we talk about "ultrawide" monitor, not "super ultrawide" :D it's a bit over the top to start with a 32:9 ! :D
ofc i understand the appeal to work with a 32:9 monitor, but as you guessed it, OLED aren't really for desk work, the pixel response time and HDR capability are for gaming and movies ! that's what i did less than a year now, buying the Samsung OLED G8 ( same as yours but 21:9) and it's awesome ! it has his drawback, like, it's also a smartTV and after coming back from sleep, sometime the computer don't even know the screen is here, but from an image quality perspective, it's nearly perfect !

also, about burn in, yes, the result of Monitor Unboxed are encouraging, but a monitor is meant (usually) to be used between 5 to 10 year ! it's not something you change every year or two ! so, ok, good result for now, but as for me, i'm removing ANY KIND of wallpaper and put a pitch black background ! you see, OLED burn in are made because the pixels are used ! not because the thing are static on screen, just because they "work" ! and on an OLED, when it's black, i mean TRUE black, pixel just .... don't work at all ! it's not a technique, it's how they work, so, a black background and very agressive auto shutdown when inactive are the most powerfull tool to keep your preeeeciooooousssssss monitor alive longer !

welcome in the ultrawide family :D

comments.comment_text_display: @vicmanpergar same. I've been using an OLED TV with a laptop for media consumption, and it's worked very well. However, I've left it on without a screen saver a couple times, and it affected the pixels. It looked like burn-in; it's not, it's something called "image persistence" and was able to be cleared, it's a stepping stone, and a reminder that LCD derivatives simply don't have these worries.. SO... while OLED is great for these purposes, for a general monitor, Mini LED is a better solution.
comments.comment_text_original: @vicmanpergar same. I've been using an OLED TV with a laptop for media consumption, and it's worked very well. comments.comment_text_display: @magicmulder If you are using this for things like editors, spreadsheets, or basically anything with a button and menu bar, you will burn it into the screen eventually. My OLED TV, which only had a computer on it as a secondary use, lasted about 5 years before the screen had permanent Windows application bar burn-in. Eventually, OLED will fix the blue LED retention problem as they have some promising results in the lab, but until there is a commercial solution, I will stick to mini LED.

comments.comment_text_display:
This is why I went with the Dell Ultrawide. It is a lot taller (but not as wide). It is the older 3480x1600. Being 1600p reminds me of my older 16x10 monitors (I always loved 16x10 monitors because they were taller). I've always had 1200p or 1600p. Now of course there is that newer 5k2k one, though good luck playing games at that resolution, I guess one could cut it to a 4th and play at 1080p. It is also curved a lot less, you don't even notice it's curved when using one.
Double 16x9 bugs me, it is not tall enough, and I don't need double 16x9 over double 16x10. But 21:9 while tall enough, I wish were just a little wider. another 4-6 inches maybe.
There is no perfect ultrawide, but I'll take 21:9 over 32:9 if those are my only choices. (and they are)

comments.comment_text_display: I've been a developer for 40+ years. Had seen other developers 5, 6,+ monitors in all sorts of configurations. Finally sanity kicked in from one of my colleagues, who simply purchased a large 4k TV. Brilliant! I now have a 50" 4k Smart TV from Walmart for under $200, a single post clamp mount, and use several different pieces of software to "divide" my TV into different sections, and I have an easily reconfigurable setup that takes no desk space, and does everything I want it to. Total investment, maybe $250. Don't knock it until you try it. For this price you can't loose. If it doesn't work for you, you've got a 4k Smart TV you can use somewhere else.  Trust me, a 50" TV 2 feet in front of you is very immersive.

I think the typical screen aspect ratio is better than the ultra-wide as I don't want to have to turn my head to look from one side of my screen to the other.  I'm currently running a 43" LG OLED TV as a monitor and I really like it. I also got it on sale (which come along often) so I paid far less than a dedicated monitor of comparable size.  As far as having multiple screens open at once, that is what I use my work set up for, which is a 2-monitor system with one horizontal and one vertical.  I like the vertical monitor because I can display a full page of a document there for reference and do my work on the horizontal screen.

comments.comment_text_display:
So I picked up an Odyssey G9, around 2020/2021. At first I really liked the display, as it was a HUGE (literally and figuratively) improvement over my old screens. I also used an Ergotron monitor arm, and it performed amazingly well as a mount. Like you, I thought the original stand was a bit too bulky. I recall the one that came with mine was even bigger, and wider. It practically took up the entire desk. Though, I did say "at first", because I ended up selling the screen, about a year or so later. While I liked the width, it was a little too wide with the curve. I also wanted a taller screen, as I was getting a bit frustrated by the lack of vertical space. I also noticed that the dimming zones for HDR was very bad. It was (at the time) a VA panel, and the ghosting was really bad. It became super noticeable, even moving the mouse around. Then there were issues with gaming. Even with tools like Borderless Gaming (also useful for non-gaming stuff, btw), issues kept appearing. Like having HUD elements just spread all over the place, your HP all the way over to the top left, ammo all the way over to the bottom right, etc. Then there was issues relating to fan noise, and plastic creaking. These issues just kept pilling up, and figured the super ultrawide, at least not Samsungs vision of it, was not for me. So I ended up selling it for a LG C1 TV, a 48incher. Still big with tons of space, but a much... and I can't stress this enough, MUCH better display. I just swapped the stand out for a 3rd party one (smaller footprint), and it's been great. I do wish they had a 43inch (like the followup C2), but I don't regret the purchase.

EDIT: I really wouldn't worry about modern burn-in. Granted Samsung's version of OLED is worse for this, but I don't think the majority of folks need to worry. There is plenty of tools that the screens use to prevent burn-in. I've had my OLED TV now for about 4 years now, and it's been fine. Granted I do use dark mode... you light mode heathen.

comments.comment_text_display:
As someone who bought an ultrawide for gaming a year or two ago, I really like it. I got a 34in 3440x1440 (only 21:9) IPS flat (no curve) panel at 144hz for $300. Personally, I feel that the 32:9 ratio is a little too extreme for gaming. On 21:9 I get a little extra peripheral vision and immersiveness in my games without things looking too warped, whereas things look really stretched and weird at the edges on a 32:9. UI elements look fine when placed at either 16:9 or 21:9 locations, but putting UI elements at the end of a 32:9 space is just silly.

As for productivity, it makes doing 2 windows side by side nicer, and it makes 3 windows side by side possible when compared to 16:9. I still have a second monitor though xd.

comments.comment_text_display:
I treated myself to a big screen TV in 2005. For $2500, I got a 50" DLP - specifically because I was capable of fixing it. It lasted me for 17 years.
Knowing that electronics prices are so volatile, I avoided looking at advertisements for a while. I did find out that 2 months later, the same TV was $500 less.
Fast forward a few years, I'm helping a friend of mine without a car get his new big screen home. I mentioned to the sales guy that I had a DLP TV, but hadn't seen any in a while. He said that he saw a couple in the dollar store around the corner ü•µ That jerk-off.

I am glad that I was able to repair my TV for so long, until parts ran out. I purchased the last colour wheel for the LG DLP TV line ever.

comments.comment_text_display: We purchased a LG OLED 65' TV in late 2019. Within a year it started to show image retainement, which would go away after the TV had been turned off for a while. Within 2 years, they were permanent burn ins. We moved that TV to a Bedroom as a secondary TV. It was replaced with a LG 75' QNET TV. This has been rock solid with very good picture and 100% reliability. We are never going to buy another OLED. The difference between an OLED and a high quality LCD is simply not large enough to justify the short life of an OLED.

comments.comment_text_display:
Still have a Panasonic FullHD plasma from 2010, phenomenal picture quality (better than any modern LCD), still working flawlessly to this day. Never had to be fixed.
I have solar panels installed in my house, so the extra energy consumption is not a problem, same for heat as I don't pay a dime for leaving the A/C on the entire day if I want.
I have a bunch of old videogames attached to my plasma, it's the only FHD display tech that works well with SD content (which I also consume a lot) besides CRT, so when it finally dies I'll probably buy another plasma.
When there's not a single decent plasma available, I'll give OLED or whatever similar technology is available in the future a try.

comments.comment_text_display: @HDRSpectralScan Sony might be the dimmest but it does a great job with its tone mapping of displaying specular highlights in a more impactful way, especially when viewing in a dim or dark environment.
comments.comment_text_original: @HDRSpectralScan Sony might be the dimmest but it does a great job with its tone mapping of displaying specular highlights in a more impactful way, especially when viewing in a dim or dark environment.

comments.comment_text_display: @HDRSpectralScan Not all DTM methods are the same. These are the opinions of the TV manufacturer's on what tone mapping should be for their TVs just like the regular tone mapping algorithms they use they are all different in their own ways. Samsung (Active) and LG (DTM) I always suggest to turn off because it lifts the entire picture presentation these are more situational for bright room watching or just if it fits your preference and you simply like the look. Panasonic I say keep it on use the the dynamic setting for the tone mapping options, it seems to be similar to Sony though there are some key differences but it at least doesn't seem to ever over brighten the picture like LG (DTM) and Samsung (Active) does with their dynamic tone mapping methods.

comments.comment_text_display:
@BlackBruceLeeTheGreatDekuTree: Not strange at all once you understand the fundamental differences between Rtings‚Äô methodology and ours. Our shootout involved:

1) Using a ¬£30,000 dual-layer LED LCD reference monitor as the benchmark for comparison.

2) Applying alternate white points after perceptual matching to the reference monitor (rather than relying purely on D65 measurements) to account for differences in spectral power distributions between displays.

3) Having the TVs judged by industry professionals who work on the very content consumers watch, including major films such as Harry Potter.

4) Masking all the TVs so the judges had no idea which model they were scoring.

Under these conditions the Sony BRAVIA 8 II received higher scores than the LG G5 in our blinded shootout judged by professionals.

2) Applying alternate white points after perceptual matching to the reference monitor (rather than relying purely on D65 measurements) to account for differences in spectral power distributions between displays.

3) Having the TVs judged by industry professionals who work on the very content consumers watch, including major films such as Harry Potter.

4) Masking all the TVs so the judges had no idea which model they were scoring.

Under these conditions the Sony BRAVIA 8 II received higher scores than the LG G5 in our blinded shootout judged by professionals.

Samsung's consumer side is a menace.

comments.comment_text_display:
I miss 3D TVs... my old Samsung 3D TV (it's in my living room, so it's hardly used, since I usually watch/play games in my game room) still has an amazing picture, and watching movies or playing games in 3D is incredible. It's so dumb that it was abandoned so quickly, especially with display technology advancing so much in the last 20 years... The biggest downside to most 3D displays was the limited refresh rate ( most were 60 Hz). Since the 3D effect is achieved by showing each left/right image at alternate frames, 60 FPS content/games would often have weird camera judder. 1080p also didn't help out 3D content, since the resolution of 3D media/games was effectively halved (since it would use the left side for one view, and the right side for the other, then the TV would basically switch between each half of the displayed image). So, 3D content would often look a bit blurier than standard 2D content.
While 120 Hz 3D TVs DO exist, they were INCREDIBLY expensive, and I can honestly say I've never known anyone who had one. With how cheap 120Hz, 4K TVs have become, 4K/120 Hz 3D displays would be MUCH cheaper if they were still produced en masse. 4K @ 120 Hz would make 3D gaming sooo much smoother and easier on the eyes.

comments.comment_text_display:
@AllDayErrDay. It is also true for Micro LED. LED degrade. MicroLED degrade the same way as OLED, but slower.
MiniLED degrades too, but the degradation is rarely noticeable because it lits not individual pixels, which means the usage of LED across the screen is almost the same.

Lifespan of LED is much greater than OLED, but the limiting factor right now is not the OLED longevity, its the technology evolution itself: OLED lives long enough to make you want to repalce your TV because there is a better model, not because your curent OLED has burn-in noticeable enough.

comments.comment_text_display: I bought my TV around 2019. I wanted a non-OLED since I was connecting my PC to it and didn't want burn in. I originally bought a Samsung QLED and hated it. It looked great in store on the hyper saturated and contrasty stock footage they use, but once I got it home the adaptive black looked like a black amoeba moving around my screen. It was so distracting. Luckily, the TV developed a pink line down the middle before the return window was up. I returned it and went with a Sony that was $1000 cheaper. The bloom is a little more noticeable on it, but its so much more natural feeling. I wonder how these newer generation non-OLED Samsungs do with their dimming zones. Have they gotten more natural with their dimming by having more zones, or is it still as bad as I experienced.

And even though people have been stating "perfect blacks" for ages, many OLEDs struggle with near black level control.
QD OLEDs has been really impressive, with their own pro's and con's, but all people seem to care about is the 'brightness race' anyway.

Im glad with RGB Mini LEDs we can talk colors again. And yes also these TVs wont be perfect. Just other pro's and con's

MicroLED will be the closest to perfection, but the drawback is obvious... size and price. Pretty much not affordable for 99% of the people

comments.comment_text_display: Bought a Sony XR-77A80J in 2021 and had it ISF calibrated, wanting brighter, I started looking for its replacement and I had two main requirements, it be an OLED and size be at least 77in.  The Sony Bravia 8 II immediately was excluded from my search being its only offered in 55/65, what a shame since Sony‚Äôs processing is top notch.  Ended up with an LG OLED83G4 for several reasons, OOTB measurements are outstanding, processing closely approaches Sony, price(paid less for this 83in than I could buy others 77in, and it is more than bright enough to take advantage of the normal 1000nit material which dominates today‚Äôs video material(streaming or media).  I think Sony is weening itself off OLED to go all in on, on its next years 2026 flagship RGB Mini-LED technology.

comments.comment_text_display:
After watching both your reviews of the Samsung S95F and Sony Bravia 8 II, I have to say I was on the edge of both in terms of searching for my first splurge for an OLED.
Like you, I'm a casual gamer and own a PS5, playing primarily at my leisure compared to countless hours each weekend. The richer blacks and easier user interface turned the Sony Bravia 8 II into my first choice being quite the cinephile.
Along with the ease of install without having to deal with Samsung's One Connect Box (Sounds like a headache, although the 2.1 HDMI outlets are nice in comparison to 2.0 on the Sony Bravia). I primarily watch streaming apps; so the menu tree looks great, and easier to navigate than Samsung's.
I'm considering mounting the Bravia on the wall rather than on a stand due to space. I've got the Dolby Atmos Sound Bar on lock to aide in the sound enhancement.
Thanks for your reviews on both OLED's, and technological honesty; along with breakdowns of both tv's specs and picture abilities. Makes my decision that much easier!

comments.comment_text_display:
I‚Äôve been using LG OLED TVs since 2019, but recently I decided to switch to Sony. I bought the BRAVIA 8 II and noticed some unexpected behaviors:
1. When I applied certain settings to a specific input, then switched to another input and went back, some of the settings were reset or missing.
2. The TV outputs Dolby audio from my PS5 to my AVR, even though the PS5 is set to LPCM.
3. When I play audio from my PC (connected to the TV, with the AVR connected to the TV as well), I experience noticeable audio lag‚Äîsomething I never encountered with my LG TV.

These issues aren‚Äôt mentioned in any reviews I‚Äôve seen‚Äîyou really have to own the TV to notice them.

comments.comment_text_display: I assume you unlocked the 20-point grayscale controls using Calman software?  Even with calibration, this TV is going to be an exercise in frustration if you're after an accurate image for all content.  Sony doesn't allow for separate calibration settings for SDR and HDR10 signals.  They just take your SDR calibration settings and automatically translate and apply them to HDR10 signals.  While that sounds simpler in theory, it doesn't work very well in practice on this model.  If you share settings like this, your grayscale tracking (especially near black) is going to be terrible.  If you calibrate for accurate HDR, then SDR will have a green tint in darker grayscale shades around 5% gray.  If you calibrate for SDR, then HDR10 will have a red tint.  The only solution is to calibrate a separate picture mode and color temperature for SDR signals and another picture mode and color temperature for HDR10.  Unfortunately, the set won't switch calibration settings automatically based on signal type, so you then need to manually switch between SDR and HDR calibrated settings every time you start watching content.  What a pain!

comments.comment_text_display:
When compared to the S95F‚Ä¶.
Confirmed, the Samsungs White and all Color Luminance metrics are significantly higher which attribute its much more vibrant appearance.

When watching in a dark room however, I have not noted any issue with the Samsungs Black level. It‚Äôs only within daytime viewing where the Anti Glare which diffuses light over a larger area of the screen raises its black level when compared to the Bravia and G5. Of course you gain no ambient reflection. Sort of a pick your poison situation. Glare or raised black level. The G5 is a stunner as its WOLED panel possesses no inherent QD Black Level Rise and given it has approximately the same sustained peak brightness as the Samsung, The G5 looks really really good in a bright room. The Samsung would only be preferable in the event your ambient reflection was truly egregious.

I am so disappointed with Sony this year. They purposefully made a TV just slightly better than the A95L with terribly restricted sizes all while still charging a premium for it.

Andrew wait until you see the G5 in Filmmaker!
Video processing is much improved and the Specular Highlights are ridiculous.

Please discuss your impression as to what Sony was thinking this year‚Ä¶.
Are they attempting to push the buying public toward their Bravia 9 which I guarantee they make more money on or are they holding back and allocating resources towards RGB Mini LED?

Thank you
Great review as always

Mir pers√∂nlich ist die Technologie, die zu einem exzellenten Ergebnis f√ºhrt, egal. Wenn es mehrere, verschiedene Technologien gibt, die ein perfektes Erlebnis erm√∂glichen, bei vernachl√§ssigbaren Nebeneffekten/Nachteilen, die nicht prim√§r ergebnisorientiert sind, z.B. Unterschiede im Stromverbrauch o.√§., entscheide ich mich immer f√ºr die preiswertere Alternative.

Ich habe vor ein paar Wochen einen QD-Mini-LED TV der neuen Generation wieder zur√ºckgegeben und mir einen aktuellen OLED (2025er) gleicher Display-Gr√∂√üe zugelegt. Der OLED ist beim Schwarzwert √ºber alle Quellen hinweg um l√§ngen besser, die max. m√∂gliche Helligkeit ist mehr als ausreichend, auch in hellen Szenarien. Es war jetzt nicht die preiswertere Alternative, aber die mit dem f√ºr mich besseren Ergebnis und Erlebnis, gegen√ºber dem Mini-LED.

Dimming-Zonen: K√∂nnte eim Micro RGB TV so viele Dimming-Zonen haben, (mehr als Mini LED), dass dadurch die Darstellung von Schwarz, auch aufgrund der h√∂heren Kontraste durch Wegfall von Farbfiltern, nicht mehr vom OLED mit blo√üem Auge zu unterscheiden ist?
Mehr als "Licht AUS" geht nicht bei der Darstellung von Schwarz. Das ist der OLED mit theoretisch unendlichem Kontrast schwer zu toppen.
Bei sonst √§hnlichen Eigenschaften sind dann wieder (Beispiel hoher Stromverbrauch beim Mini-LED, wahrscheinlich auch beim Micro RGB) andere Faktoren, die den Unterschied machen.

Als OLED auf den Markt kam wurden an den TV-Ger√§ten √§hnliche Preisschilder gesichtet, wie jetzt f√ºr Micro RGB TV aufgerufen werden. Die wird sich vermutlich ja noch √§ndern.

Derzeit bin ich immer noch beim technisch mittlerweile seeeehr ausgereiften, von Kinderkrankheiten bereinigtem OLED-Display gut aufgehoben.

comments.comment_text_display:
I have the 65" S95F. Black looks black to me.

The part of the S95F not having any Dirty Screen Effect is very true for my TV.

Filmmaker mode looks good if you set Picture Clarity: Custom, Judder reduction=5. Without it, panning scenes stutter. If I enable the Blur reduction setting I can bad soap opera affect.
Some people mention that Judder reduction causes artifacts in grass, but I have not noticed that, perhaps I have not looked to closely.

Contrast I turn down from 50 to 47, or else it looks a bit harsh.
Color I turn down from 25 to 24.

I kept "Peak Brightness: High" for HDR and "Peak Brightness: Medium" for SDR, these are the default settings. If I increase peak brightness for SDR, I see too much grain in the image.

I've kept the light sensor turned on, but you can disable it under General & Privacy->Power and Energy Saving->Brightness Optimization if you want to ensure max brightness.

I have my TV on a stand close to the wall. Placed like this the built-in speakers sound slightly better than I would have expected from such a thin TV.

comments.comment_text_display: I don't understand how the One Connect box is downside.  I guess if you want to wall mount, and you have nothing else to plug into it, it would be a pain.  If you have a gaming console or two, and an Apple TV, you have to put all of those somewhere.  So you put all of those with the One Connect, and run one thin cable to the TV.  It's a game changer in that scenario.

comments.comment_text_display: S95D owner here - coming from a Panasonic Viera Plasma (12 years old but I loved it).  In Florida, the anti-glare feature is amazing!  Also, at night we can watch movies and when people turn on a light in the kitchen, there is NO reflection.   Also, love the one connect.  With a slim fit wall mount, it looks very clean.  One wire going from TV, down the wall and into the one connect that sits in our media center/TV stand.   Paired with our Samsung Soundbar, which Q Symphony takes up a notch.    We keep in movie or filmmaker mode.  Had to turn off ALL of the smoothing as the Soap Opera effect was just too much for us coming from the older plasma.   Gaming is incredible.   I could care less about the software as we use Apple TV for everything.  I highly recommend this TV for anyone.  If you live in a house with a lot of natural light this is a no brainer.  If you, like me, watch TV when other people have lights on, this is also a no brainer.  ZERO reflection.

comments.comment_text_display: Well, I'm old enough to remember the crap TVs of the past and how much they cost. The fact of the matter is we live in an age where we have unbelievable image quality and value for even the cheapest TVs. I just bought a $200 LG 43" 4K to use as a monitor for my Mac mini and I also get a TV out of it. The computing experience on it is amazing. Pin sharp text and screen elements, and images and videos. When used as a TV I'm blown away by the image quality. The detail is incredible. The contrast is great. The color is accurate. Viewing angles are excellent. The black levels are far better than my old plasma TV. Couldn't be happier with the purchase and especially the value, now as a senior.

comments.comment_text_display: @andrewrobinsonreviews What impressed me with this generation of OLED from Samsung is that they bridged the gap in a meaningful way to their mini LEDs in terms of brightness. When the S95D is next to the QN90D, the QN model certainly appears brighter, with white highlights far more punchy. But with the S95F next to the QN90F, white highlights appear very similar, and full screen brightness doesn't fall far behind unless most of the screen is white. The % increase between generations might be as expected, but it makes it far easier to recommend OLED

comments.comment_text_display:
Great review. The S95F isn't the top flagship OLED this year, but the competition doesn't offer a clearly superior alternative. The Panasonic comes with a hefty price premium of ‚Ç¨2,000, Sony's model is limited to 65 inches, and the LG G5 still suffers from firmware issues.
Ultimately, I hesitated between the LG G5 and the Samsung S95F, but I chose the S95F. Initially, I was put off by the matte screen, but seeing it in-store changed my perspective: it doesn't look cheap and actually handles reflections better than I expected, making me think about my tolerance for glare.
Overall, the S95F is a compelling option despite some compromises. It holds special significance for me: my first flat-screen TV was a Samsung 20 years ago. After owning a Sony, a Panasonic, and then a LG, it feels like I'm cycling through the same sequence again.
Final note: that CANVAS TV stand has a perfect design. A manufacturer should derive this concept for a central channel speaker with this form factor (or start a partnership with CANVAS).

comments.comment_text_display:
Hello !

You've correctly raised the details regarding DV, Tayzen, etc., but their global leadership positions shouldn't encourage them to change course much, lol

Seeing Netflix offering HDR10+, it's more like the market is slowly adapting to them.

I'm not a big fan of Samsung; I've always been a Sony (and a little Panasonic) fan in recent years. But I have to say that the QD OLED mix (with all its positives) and the matte-coated panel really impressed me. The blacks get deeper as light pollution decreases.

For me, blaming Samsung's coating for a lack of contrast is like blaming a movie theater for making us watch a movie in the dark, lol.

I use an Apple TV, so Tayzen doesn't bother me at all.

The main reason I'm not buying a Samsung is because the upscaling is inferior to the others (especially Sony).

YouTube channels love to rave about HDR performance, but I still watch a lot of programs in SDR, bcs I'm from Paris, and in France we don't have many TV programs (shows, movies, sports, anime) in HDR yet, I have all the Netflix, Amazon Prime or Disney+ subscriptions to have a choice, but in SDR. so it's very important.

You're going to get the B8II; it's an excellent model. Sony could have pushed the brightness further; it's way behind the competition, even though the price isn't üòÖ

They probably don't want to compete too much with the B9, which remains THE flagship model.

By the way, I'd like you to give us a little bit of your opinion on the market compared to what you've already tested overall, and your specific impression of the Bravia 9 and the Bravia 8 II, because I'm hesitating between the two for my next TV.

My 2020 Oled tv Sony A8H is good, but it's slowly starting to fall behind since the arrival of the Bravia 9 and the QD OLED, lol

Thank you for the complete and honest review!
comments.comment_text_original:
Hello !

You've correctly raised the details regarding DV, Tayzen, etc., but their global leadership positions shouldn't encourage them to change course much, lol

Seeing Netflix offering HDR10+, it's more like the market is slowly adapting to them.

I'm not a big fan of Samsung; I've always been a Sony (and a little Panasonic) fan in recent years. But I have to say that the QD OLED mix (with all its positives) and the matte-coated panel really impressed me. The blacks get deeper as light pollution decreases.

For me, blaming Samsung's coating for a lack of contrast is like blaming a movie theater for making us watch a movie in the dark, lol.

I use an Apple TV, so Tayzen doesn't bother me at all.

The main reason I'm not buying a Samsung is because the upscaling is inferior to the others (especially Sony). 

YouTube channels love to rave about HDR performance, but I still watch a lot of programs in SDR, bcs I'm from Paris, and in France we don't have many TV programs (shows, movies, sports, anime) in HDR yet, I have all the Netflix, Amazon Prime or Disney+ subscriptions to have a choice, but in SDR. so it's very important.

You're going to get the B8II; it's an excellent model. Sony could have pushed the brightness further; it's way behind the competition, even though the price isn't üòÖ

They probably don't want to compete too much with the B9, which remains THE flagship model.

By the way, I'd like you to give us a little bit of your opinion on the market compared to what you've already tested overall, and your specific impression of the Bravia 9 and the Bravia 8 II, because I'm hesitating between the two for my next TV.

My 2020 Oled tv Sony A8H is good, but it's slowly starting to fall behind since the arrival of the Bravia 9 and the QD OLED, lol

Thank you for the complete and honest review!

comments.comment_text_display: @gunnarsandberg8132The pixels won't ever have a problem with dimming in dark scenes. (When talking about oleds). Every single pixel will shut itself down completely when the content requires it. Low-luminance grays are sensitive to any voltage/brightness fluctuations, so banding is more likely. And sometimes the pixel refresh cycle can help even it out on brand new panels.

Hi guys,
I need to replace my old Samsung LED 55KS7000, which is now too obsolete.
I typically use it in the living room for movies (especially Blu-ray Rip to MKV directly from an external HDD), TV, Netflix, etc.
All combined with a 5.1 system with a Denon amplifier.
Looking online, I understand that the following models are competing:
- LG 55 G5
- SAMSUNG S95F
- SONY BRAVIA 8 II
- PANASONIC Z95B
Unfortunately, I've seen so many reviews and am now confused about which one to choose.
I await your more expert advice.

comments.comment_text_display:
‚Äã@yenneferofgyanvapi3965I'm of the opposite opinion - an entry level OLED like the B5 really pales in comparison to even the C4.
It lacks the HDR impact. People say brightness doesn't matter, but it's useless brightness that doesn't matter. Having the headroom of brightness gives you better shadow detail and makes scenes pop. People wouldn't be buying C5s and G5s if blacks were the only thing that matters in picture quality.

comments.comment_text_display: I have the same setup with a Denon AVR in the livingroom. I would choose the Panasonic. Stacked OLED is supposed to get rid of the purple reflections QD OLED gives from window light on blacks. So that leaves only the LG. Panasonic is an LG with better Sony like calibrated colors and components and has an extra passive cooling of which I think makes it last longer. I also heard that blue breaks the fastest but because blue has a double layer in stacked OLED, it doesn‚Äôt need to work as hard as one layer blue, so therefore the least lasting color lasts longer if that information is correct.

I am having very bad experience of 55 VU TV. After 3 years of working it started losing color balance at left side , very very disappointed for me when I used to had trust VU as a luxury brand smart tv. I now came to a conclusion that any brand , inspite of tall claim does not give reliable products, for a simple reason
1. They deliberately want to keep lifespan limited say only 3 years
2. Cultivating " use and throw " so that customer forcefully require to buy a new one
3. Picture quality may found deteriorated after 2+ years

So in nutshell there is no point carefully reviewing any neutral or promoted comparative review

‚≠ê TCL C6K ‚Äì A Truly Wow Experience! ‚≠ê

This comment is especially for those who are looking to buy a TV with great features at an affordable price ‚Äî look no further than the TCL C6K!

I recently bought the TCL C6K from Vijay Sales with a 2-year extended warranty, and honestly, it has exceeded all my expectations! The picture quality, 4K upscaling, and the immersive Onkyo sound powered by Mini LED technology make this TV an absolute delight to watch.

The visuals are stunning ‚Äî rich colors, deep contrast, and sharp clarity that truly bring every frame to life. I even compared it side-by-side with the Sony Bravia 2, and to my surprise, the C6K panel looked even better!

TCL is really stepping up its game, offering premium performance and top-tier features at an unbeatable price.

Totally happy and impressed ‚Äî TCL is doing amazing things! üëèüî•
